name: vulnerability-web-httpheader-strncpy
description: Multiple unvalidated strncpy calls were identified in HTTP response handling, where source strings could originate from HTTP response headers. The specific manifestations include: 1) Extracting X-Error-Code and X-Error-Message headers from HTTP responses; 2) Using strncpy to copy them into local buffers; 3) Failing to adequately validate the length of source strings. This may lead to buffer overflow or information disclosure vulnerabilities.
notes: Confirm the target buffer size. Although not directly related to HTTP request parameter processing, it falls under web component security issues. The dangerous function is strncpy, with the data source being HTTP response headers.

name: web-genie.cgi-QUERY_STRING-snprintf
notes: Verify all processing paths of the QUERY_STRING parameter

name: web-genie.cgi-X-Error-Code-strncpy
description: The X-Error-Code and X-Error-Message headers are processed using strncpy in the error handling path. Although the buffer size is constrained, it could still be exploited maliciously. Maliciously crafted HTTP responses may trigger this vulnerability.
notes: Enhance boundary checks for HTTP header processing

name: web-genie.cgi-popen-hardcoded
description: The popen function call uses hardcoded parameters, which currently poses a low risk, but may introduce command injection vulnerabilities if the parameter handling logic is modified.
notes: Regular audits are required to monitor the use of dangerous functions such as popen.
